author: chefkaspa
title: Neither fish nor meat
review:
Box

I always compare completed model with its box because that's what you see in store before buying it (or not).

This one has the same front size as set 42079 but 1" (2.5 cm) less height. This surprised me because it doesn't represent the parts count (827 resp. 592).

Assembly

You start with a couple of sandwiched frame pieces that eventually become the basis of the chassis.
Next, rear part with the winch will be build. This is a first for me: This unit is attached to the chassis bit only by the two knob wheels during build. Then, side panels will be added to provide stability.

I postponed the cabin until the end because I was more curious about the front part. It can easily be added later as it gets attached to the turntable by two 1x2 beams.

The lifting mechanism for the logs gets only as much attention (and parts) as necessary. The "claw" with its many yellow teeth is impressive but the arm behind appears too thin.

Last, the base with tracks is built. This is refreshing as a new way of installing the track rollers is used. I believe that this could be useful for other models as well. I am always surprised that stability can be achieved with few parts: left and right track are combined with two 15M beams and four connectors only . The whole module is then attached to the chassis using four 3L (axle) pins.

Without stickers the completed model looks something like a bumblebee: There is too much contrast between yellow and black parts. (For comparison: The earth blue-and-yellow of the 42079 fork lift is much more pleasing.)

My thoughts

Pro's

  • Unique set idea
  • There are no parts in strange colours used for this model.
  • Track - new clever setup for rollers, sturdy, easily attachable by four pins
  • Winch - two speed from gear box that doesn't need surplus of gear wheels
  • Cabin - is highly detailed even with opening doors. However, rotation by knobwheel apears too much. Two positions, facing front and back (cf. Claas) would have been sufficient.

Con's

  • Loader - while the 'grabbing' thing looks impressive, the arm and mechanics just don't deliver. From side it looks flimsy. To grab a log you have to operate a small lever on the arm itself. I only gave it a few tries until I got disappointed. It just doesn't work well.
    There is plenty of space within the chassis to have the second function operated from the back. (Did you ever play with 856 bulldozer? IMO that has still the best manually operated setup.)
  • Logs - Are built from 2x2 round bricks. Last years set 42080 hat those with profile.

Why?

I bought the set for parts when it was on 30% discount.

author: Takenusername
title: was excited...then DUN DUN DUN...
review: i was really excited to get this set, the tracked loader. Upon completion, as a seemingly straight forward build i started to notice things. The cab CONSTANTLY moving, the pair of arms that are suppose to grip the "load" constantly letting them slip out...oh? did i mention it cannot seem to grasp its own load, ever. i give +1 for tracks
